It misunderstands that positive OCI adjustments reduce liabilities, while negative ones increase them. This is a fundamental error in pension accounting logic. The U.S. Bank Subsidiaries are subject to regulatory capital requirements, and the adoption of CECL has been phased in over five years, with 75% phased-in as of 2024 and full implementation effective January 1, 2025. This phased-in approach has delayed the full capital impact of CECL, meaning the credit loss provisions from commercial real estate loans have not yet fully affected the risk-based capital ratios. Because the U.S. bank subsidiaries must remain “well‑capitalized” under OCC rules, this reduction in retained earnings can constrain the amount of capital they can hold, potentially lowering their risk‑based capital ratios (CET1, Tier 1 and Total) and, if the ratios fall close to the required minimums, triggering restrictions on capital‑distribution activities. The phased‑in CECL transition (75 % of the CECL impact recognized in 2024) means that a portion of the higher provision will be reflected in the capital calculations, further pressuring the subsidiaries’ capital buffers. Consequently, the higher CRE‑loan provision can weaken the subsidiaries’ capital position and may limit their ability to meet regulatory capital requirements and make capital distributions.
